On Mon, 2003-07-21 at 16:56, korosh_afshar wrote:
> I have a need to spawn a server and multiple clients in different VM's 
> because of singleton use of a library that each client uses which 
> limits me to this solution.   Server starts, then clients each start 
> and interact with the server and make assertions on the response from 
> server.

Hmm.  Well, one thing you might consider is that, depending on how
useful the library is, it might be easiest to change the clients so that
they don't use that library.

> I'd like to do this from ONE TestCase since that seems like a nicer 
> solution than Ant parallel task.  e.g my TestClientServer  would spawn 
> a server in a different VM and also spawn as many clients as I want 
> each in its own VM and then once all client(s) test methods are done, 
> the TestClientServer tears down.
> Is there a way to do this.

There is a way to do anything.  If you mean:  "Does the JUnit framework
provide a facility that will let me do this easily?" then the answer is
"No."  You will have to provide such a facility yourself.

It doesn't seem to me as though it will be a very difficult thing to do,
though.  For example: you could use one of the exec methods in Runtime
to spawn the other VM processes.

How will your test method make assertions about what has happened in the
server VM, or the client VMs?  You'll have to have some way of allowing
communication between the various virtual machines.  The easiest ways I
can think of are:

- server and client programs communicate with their parent process (i.e.
the test method) using standard input and output (after spawning a new
Process using Runtime.exec(...), you would use the getInputStream() and
getOutputStream() methods of the resulting Process to establish
communications with the spawned program).

- server and client programs communicate with their parent process using
network connections -- perhaps the server and clients create
ServerSockets bound to ports you specify using a startup argument, and
the test method creates sockets to communicate with those ports.

Cheers,
